speaker: Nurse
text_entry: SCENE IV. A street.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter ROMEO, MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, with five or six Maskers, Torch-bearers, and others

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Or shall we on without a apology?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The date is out of such prolixity:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: After the prompter, for our entrance:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But let them measure us by what they will;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being but heavy, I will bear the light.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And soar with them above a common bound.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Under love's heavy burden do I sink.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And, to sink in it, should you burden love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Too great oppression for a tender thing.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is love a tender thing? it is too rough,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: If love be rough with you, be rough with love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Give me a case to put my visage in:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A visor for a visor! what care I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: What curious eye doth quote deformities?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But every man betake him to his legs.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A torch for me: let wantons light of heart

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nay, that's not so.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I mean, sir, in delay

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Five times in that ere once in our five wits.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And we mean well in going to this mask;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But 'tis no wit to go.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Why, may one ask?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I dream'd a dream to-night.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And so did I.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Well, what was yours?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That dreamers often lie.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: In shape no bigger than an agate-stone

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: On the fore-finger of an alderman,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Drawn with a team of little atomies

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The traces of the smallest spider's web,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The collars of the moonshine's watery beams,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Not so big as a round little worm

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And in this state she gallops night by night

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Then dreams, he of another benefice:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And sleeps again. This is that very Mab

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That plats the manes of horses in the night,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That presses them and learns them first to bear,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Making them women of good carriage:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This is she--

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou talk'st of nothing.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: True, I talk of dreams,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which are the children of an idle brain,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which is as thin of substance as the air

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And more inconstant than the wind, who wooes

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Even now the frozen bosom of the north,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And, being anger'd, puffs away from thence,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I fear, too early: for my mind misgives

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Some consequence yet hanging in the stars

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Shall bitterly begin his fearful date

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With this night's revels and expire the term

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Of a despised life closed in my breast

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By some vile forfeit of untimely death.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But He, that hath the steerage of my course,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Strike, drum.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Exeunt
